ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Respondent
Looks toward parent or caregiver when hearing parent's or caregiver's voice.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Looks toward parent or caregiver who is gesturing to get his/her attention.
Responds to his or her name spoken (for example, turns toward speaker, smiles, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: When parent or caregiver looks or points at something, looks in that direction.
Understands at least 10 words.
Responds appropriately to at least three basic gestures (for example, head nod for yes, head shake for no, hand out for give me, reaching, waving, clapping).
Understands the meaning of no.
Responds appropriately to at least three facial expressions being made by others (for example, frown, smile, surprised look, angry face).
Understands the meaning of yes.
Follows instructions requiring only one action (for example, "Sit down"; "Come here").
Points to common objects in a book or magazine as they are named (for example, dog, car, cup, key, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Understands at least 50 words.
Responds to the tone of spoken words (for example, approaches eagerly when "Come here" is spoken lovingly, but hesitantly when "Come here" is spoken sharply).
Points to at least three major body parts when asked (for example, nose, mouth, hands, feet, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Follows instructions with one action and one object (for example, "Bring me the book"; "Close the door"; etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Responds appropriately to at least three more advanced gestures (for example, motioning come here, finger over lips meaning be quiet, hands apart to show this big).
Identifies at least three objects pictured in a book, magazine, or electronic screen when asked (for example, points to a dog, car, cup, key, etc.).
Identifies at least three body parts pictured in a book, magazine, or electronic screen when asked (for example, points to a nose, a mouth, hands, feet, etc.).
Responds to questions that use what (for example, when asked "What is this?" replies "A ball").
Responds to questions that use who (for example, when asked "Who is that?" replies "Auntie Kesha").
Identifies at least three basic actions pictured in a book, magazine, or electronic screen when asked (for example, points
Responds to questions that use where (for example, when asked "Where did Felipe go?" points where Felipe went).
Follows instructions with two related actions (for example, "Pick up those toys and put them away"; "Get your coat and put it on").
Follows instructions with one action and two objects (for example, "Bring me the crayons and the ball"; "Put on your shirt and your shoes").
Follows instructions in "if-then" form (for example, "If you're thirsty, then get a drink"; "If you are cold, then get a sweatshirt").
Listens to a story for at least 15 minutes.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Responds to questions that use why? (for example, when asked Why are you crying? replies My toy broke).
Follows instructions with two unrelated actions (for example, "Turn off the TV and get my keys").
Responds to questions that use when (for example, when asked "When do you eat breakfast?" replies "In the morning").
Pays attention to a show for at least 30 minutes and understands what is happening.
Identifies left and right on own body, including hands, feet, arms, legs, etc.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Follows three-part instructions (for example"Brush your teeth get dressed and make your bed" etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999

ElementDescription: Pays attention to a show for at least 60 minutes and understands what is happening.
Understands sarcasm (for example, understands when a comment such as "That's just great!" really means "That's awful!").
Pays attention to a 15-minute informational presentation and understands what is being said.
Follows instructions involving left and right (for example, "Go to the left"; "Look to the right").
When instructed to do something up to an hour later, remembers to do it (for example, "When your show is over, put your dishes in the sink").
When instructed to do something several hours later, remembers to do it (for example, "When you get home from school, let the dog out").
Pays attention to a 30-minute informational presentation and understands what is being said.
Makes sounds of pleasure (for example, coos, laughs, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Cries or fusses when uncomfortable (thirsty, hungry, wet, etc.).
Makes sounds or gestures (for example, waves arms) to get parent's or care-givers attention.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Makes at least three one-syllable speech sounds (for example, "Mah," "Bah," "Ee," "Oh").
Babbles in strings of sounds (for example, "Ba-ba-ba-ba," "Ma-ma-ma-ma," "Da-da-da-da").
Makes sounds or gestures (for example, shakes head) if he or she wants an activity to stop or keep going.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Says "Da-da" "Ma-ma" or another name for parent or caregiver including parents or caregivers first name or nickname.

ElementDescription: Uses at least three basic gestures (for example, head nod for yes, head shake for no, reaching or pointing toward something desired, waving, clapping).
"Repeats or tries to repeat common words immediately upon hearing for them (for example, ball, car, go, etc.)"
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Says "No"; must actually mean no, not just repeat the word.
Names at least three objects (for example, bottle, dog, favorite toy, etc.)

ElementDescription: Says "Yes"; must actually mean yes, not just repeat the word.

Calls brothers, sisters, or friends by their name or nickname.

ElementDescription: Uses phrases with a noun and a verb (for example, "Katie stay"; "Go home"; etc.).

ElementDescription: Uses pronouns to refer to self; grammar need not be correct (for example, "Give me," "Me want," "Mine toy").
Uses simple words to describe things (for example, dirty, pretty, big, loud, etc.).

ElementDescription: Tells about experiences in simple sentences (for example, "Ginger and I play"; "Dan read me a book"; etc.).

ElementDescription: Uses at least three more advanced gestures (for example, motioning come here, finger over lips meaning be quiet, hands apart to show this big).
Uses negatives in sentences (for example, "Me no go"'; "I won't drink it"; etc.); grammar is not important.

ElementDescription: Says correct age when asked; holding up correct number of fingers counts.

ElementDescription: Uses "and" in phrases or sentences (for example: "Mom and Dad"; "I want ice cream and cake"; etc.).

ElementDescription: Asks questions beginning with who (for example, "Who's that?"; "Who went to the store?"); just asking "Who?" (one word) doesn't count.
Uses plural nouns (for example, "Two cats," "More crackers," "Those flowers").
Uses pronouns in phrases or sentences; must use correct gender and form of the pronoun, but sentences need not be grammatically correct (for example, "He done it"; "They went"; etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Uses in, on, or under in phrases or sentences (for example, "Ball go under chair"; "Put it on the table"; etc.).

ElementDescription:
Asks questions beginning with why (for example, "Why do I have to go?"; "Why did you put my stuff away?");
just asking "Why?" (one word) doesn't count.
Says first and last name when asked.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Uses pronouns correctly; pronoun gender and grammar must be correct (for example, "I want," "Their ball," "Call her").
Asks questions beginning with when (for example, "When is dinner?"; "When can we go home?"; etc.).

ElementDescription: Uses because in phrases or sentences (for example, "Because I want to," "Kathy went home because she was sick").
Says his/her age at next birthday correctly when asked; holding up correct number of fingers counts.
Uses regular past tense verbs (for example, walked, baked, etc.); may use irregular past tense verbs ungrammatically (for example, "I runned away"; etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; DK = Don't know; 999=missing/NA

ElementDescription: Tells the basic parts of a familiar story or book or movie plot (the characters, what happens, how it ends, etc.).
Uses behind or in front of in phrases or sentences (for example: "I walked in front of her"; "Terrell is behind you" etc.).

ElementDescription: Gives simple directions involving one or two steps (for example, how to make, find, or do something).
Uses compound sentences joined by and or but (for example, "She asked me, and 1 told her no"; "Jerome wanted to go, but I didn't").
Uses own knowledge or opinions to describe or comment on things, situations, and emotions (for example, says, "I think he's mad at her because she said mean things about him"; etc.).

ElementDescription: Tells about experiences in detail (for example, tells who was involved, where activity took etc.).

ElementDescription: Cuts out complex shapes (for example, stars, animals, alphabet letters, etc.).

ElementDescription: Ties a secure bow (for example, shoe laces, gift wrapping).
Manipulates very small objects (for example, sets hands on a watch, threads a sewing needle, glues miniature model parts).
Assembles, builds, or creates complex building toy structures, model sets, homemade jewelry, arts and crafts, etc.
Is overly needy or dependent (for example, insists on help even when he/she does not need it, clings to parent or teacher).
Has eating difficulties (for example, eats too fast or too slowly, hoards food, overeats, refuses to eat, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Has sleep difficulties (for example, sleepwalks, has frequent nightmares, sleeps significantly more or less than typical for his or her age).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Refuses to go to school or work, or has to come home, because of worrying, sadness, nervousness, etc.
Is extremely anxious or nervous.
Is sad for no clear reason.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Avoids interacting with others (withdraws, prefers to be alone, etc.).
Lacks interest in doing things that he/she enjoys or used to enjoy.
Is extremely fearful of one or more common objects or situations (for example, heights, snakes, elevators).
Worries for no clear reason.
Is very irritable or moody.
Feels helpless or hopeless (for example, says that things are bad and will never get better).
Complains of feeling sick, exhausted, or in pain, even though there is no medical reason.
Has temper tantrums: Screams, cries, kicks, etc.
Intentionally disobeys and defies those in authority.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Bullies others physically or with words.
Lies, cheats, or steals.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Is physically aggressive (for example, hits, kicks, bites, etc.).
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Is stubborn or argues.
Is verbally abusive (that is, hurts others on purpose with insults, put-downs, etc.).
Breaks rules or laws because of peer pressure.
Is much more active or restless than others his/her age (for example, moves all the time, cannot sit still, fidgets).
Uses school or work property (for example, telephone, Internet access, office supplies, etc.) for unapproved personal purposes.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Sometimes or partially; 2 = Usually; 999 = Don't know/missing/NA

ElementDescription: Destroys own or another's possessions on purpose.
Gets fixated on objects or parts of objects (for example, stares at spinning wheels or fan blades, lines up objects, flips light switches over and over).
Talks about hearing voices that others do not hear, or seeing things that others do not see.
Displays behaviors that cause injury to self (for example, bangs head, hits or bites self, tears at skin, etc.).
Uses bizarre speech (for example, has conversations with self in public, speaks in phrases or sentences that have no meaning, repeats same word or phrase over and over, etc.).
Loses awareness of what is happening around him/her (for example, seems to be "in a fog," "zones out").
Repeats physical movements over and over (for example, rocks back and forth, spins, flaps hands).
Has toileting accidents (that is, wets or soils self when not in diapers).
Eats non-food items such as dirt, paste, or soap.
Engages in compulsive behavior (for example, repeated hand washing, repeatedly checking and rechecking something, other compulsive rituals).
Shows far more interest in weapons or extreme violence than others his/her age.
Harms animals (for example, tortures or kills pets or wild animals).
Has beliefs that are not true (for example, believes he/she has a "true" identity or "special" powers, believes that others secretly want to cause harm).
Gets so fixated on a particular topic that it annoys others (for example, trains, reptiles, maps, subway systems).
Talks about killing himself/herself or has tried to kill self.
Has no response to pain (for example, does not cry or seek help when cut, bruised, or badly hurt).
Wanders, darts away, or takes off from home, school, or someone watching him/her without regard for safety.
Threatens to hurt or kill someone.
Is tricked by others into doing something that could seriously harm him or her, or someone else.
Gets fixated on a person in a way that is annoying or intrusive to that person.
Engages in unwanted sexual behavior (for example, unwanted comments, unwanted physical contact, exposing himself/herself, masturbating in public, having sex at school or work).
